Situation1: They maintain daily communication with their parents, sharing detailed updates and responding promptly to messages.
Situation2: They are listed as the sole speaker for this week's congregational sermon, and the community has publicized their topic.
Story: My phone buzzed with a message from my mother just as I was reviewing my notes for the Friday sermon. “Call me when you can, beta. Need to talk.” I glanced at the clock—forty minutes until the khutbah. As a son, I’ve always made it a point to answer my parents quickly, sharing my day and listening to theirs. It’s our ritual, and I know how much it means to them, especially since I moved out. But today, as the imam, I’m the only one scheduled to deliver the sermon. The community has been anticipating my talk on unity all week; the posters are up, and people have sent in questions. My phone vibrates again—my father this time, “Are you there?” I feel the weight of both worlds pressing in. My parents expect my attention, my voice, my presence. My congregation expects my guidance, my preparation, my calm. I stare at my phone, heart pounding, torn between the call of family and the call of faith, knowing I can’t give both what they need from me in this moment.
